thread.title: Minor Allegedly Assaulted After Predatory Online Interaction
thread.title_full: Minor Allegedly Assaulted After Predatory Online Interaction

title: Minor Allegedly Assaulted After Predatory Online Interaction
text:
Minor Allegedly Assaulted After Predatory Online Interaction Four Men Arrested In Connection Montana Maclachlan , KEYT - KCOY - KKFX Digital Journalist, montana.maclachlan@keyt.com POSTED: 06:20 PM PDT Sep 11, 2015 Tweet OXNARD, Calif. - 
In the most recent case of cyber danger, four men from the Oxnard-Thousand Oaks area were arrested between Aug. 18 and Sept. 5 for allegedly sexually assaulting a 15-year-old female minor after “enticing and exploiting” her online repeatedly. Related Content Atascadero Man Arrested For Attempted Murder of SLO Woman 
The Oxnard Police Department Family Protection Unit arrested Shawn Light, 29, of Camarillo, Daniel Loza, 20, of Oxnard, Cody Mewbourne, 26, of Thousand Oaks, and Constantine Mantis, 64, of Moorpark after several weeks of investigating. 
Officials said they intercepted and arrested Light and Loza on the evening of Aug. 18, when the pair arrived at a disclosed location in Oxnard to meet the minor and commit sexual acts. 
Mewbourne also made arrangements to meet the child on another evening but did not show up as planned. He was then arrested on Sept 5. For child annoying, arranging to meet a child for sexual acts and sending harmful matter to a child. 
Deputies served an outstanding warrant for Mantis who was arrested for child annoying and sending harmful matter to a child. 
Investigators say the suspects were aware the child was under the age of 18. Criminal charges were filed against all subjects. 
The Oxnard Police Department wants to remind the public to be diligent when monitoring children’s online activity to ensure they are protected and safe. 
Anyone with information regarding this case is encouraged to contact the National Center of Missing and Exploited Children at www.missingkids.com or their local police department. If you wish to remain anonymous, you mall call the violent crimes hotline at 805-982-7070.
